articles.headline: Lael Brainard’s Steady Rise Could Culminate in Treasury Secretary Post
articles.snippet: The Fed governor is seen as a top candidate for the job, though some progressives try to paint her as a centrist who was soft on China.
articles.abstract: The Fed governor is seen as a top candidate for the job, though some progressives try to paint her as a centrist who was soft on China.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the Federal Reserve voted to “tailor” post-crisis financial regulations for all but the largest banks in October 2019, Gov. Lael Brainard cast the lone “no” vote.

articles.headline: The Husband-and-Wife Team Behind the Leading Vaccine to Solve Covid-19
articles.snippet: The German company BioNTech, founded by two scientists, has teamed up with Pfizer on a vaccine that was found to be more than 90 percent effective.
articles.abstract: The German company BioNTech, founded by two scientists, has teamed up with Pfizer on a vaccine that was found to be more than 90 percent effective.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two years ago, Dr. Ugur Sahin took the stage at a conference in Berlin and made a bold prediction. Speaking to a roomful of infectious disease experts, he said his company might be able to use its so-called messenger RNA technology to rapidly develop a vaccine in the event of a global pandemic.

articles.headline: Why a Trump Loss May Be No Match for Rupert Murdoch’s Realpolitik
articles.snippet: Fox News has lasted through “multiple presidents, and they’re going to be around for multiple more,” said one right-wing media executive.
articles.abstract: Fox News has lasted through “multiple presidents, and they’re going to be around for multiple more,” said one right-wing media executive.
articles.lead_paragraph: Presidents come and go. Rupert Murdoch remains.

articles.headline: As Hospitalizations Soar, El Paso Brings In New Mobile Morgues
articles.snippet: The nation hit a record number of coronavirus hospitalizations on Tuesday. The feared third wave has left cities like El Paso struggling with overloaded I.C.U. wards and scarce staffing.
articles.abstract: The nation hit a record number of coronavirus hospitalizations on Tuesday. The feared third wave has left cities like El Paso struggling with overloaded I.C.U. wards and scarce staffing.
articles.lead_paragraph: EL PASO — Coronavirus patients filled beds on one floor. Then two. Then the University Medical Center, a teaching hospital in El Paso, set up tents to care for patients in a parking lot. A downtown convention center became a field hospital. To free up even more space, the state began airlifting dozens of intensive care patients to other cities.

articles.headline: Fighting Election Results, Trump Employs a New Weapon: The Government
articles.snippet: As President Trump and his administration insist he didn’t lose, the rest of the world has increasingly moved to accept Joe Biden’s victory.
articles.abstract: As President Trump and his administration insist he didn’t lose, the rest of the world has increasingly moved to accept Joe Biden’s victory.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump, facing the prospect of leaving the White House in defeat in just 70 days, is harnessing the power of the federal government to resist the results of an election that he lost, something that no sitting president has done in American history.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Lara Jakes

articles.headline: The Times Called Officials in Every State: No Evidence of Voter Fraud
articles.snippet: The president and his allies have baselessly claimed that rampant voter fraud stole victory from him. Officials contacted by The Times said that there were no irregularities that affected the outcome.
articles.abstract: The president and his allies have baselessly claimed that rampant voter fraud stole victory from him. Officials contacted by The Times said that there were no irregularities that affected the outcome.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Election officials in dozens of states representing both political parties said that there was no evidence that fraud or other irregularities played a role in the outcome of the presidential race, amounting to a forceful rebuke of President Trump’s portrait of a fraudulent election.
articles.byline: By Nick Corasaniti, Reid J. Epstein and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: Black Voters Helped Deliver Biden a Presidential Victory. Now What?
articles.snippet: Joe Biden thanked Black voters in his victory speech, saying “you’ve always had my back, and I’ll have yours.” But many remained skeptical that he would usher in real change.
articles.abstract: Joe Biden thanked Black voters in his victory speech, saying “you’ve always had my back, and I’ll have yours.” But many remained skeptical that he would usher in real change.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Race affects our lives in countless ways. To read more stories on race from The New York Times, sign up here for our Race/Related newsletter.]
articles.byline: By John Eligon and Audra D. S. Burch

articles.headline: The Surging Coronavirus Finds a Federal Leadership Vacuum
articles.snippet: The winter wave has been anticipated for months. Now that it’s here, health officials worry once again about strategy and supplies.
articles.abstract: The winter wave has been anticipated for months. Now that it’s here, health officials worry once again about strategy and supplies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When senior Food and Drug Administration officials held their morning call one day this week, they received a sobering warning from the agency’s chief, Dr. Stephen M. Hahn, who had just gotten off the phone with the White House: Block out “all the craziness” afoot and stay focused on fighting the pandemic, he said.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg, Noah Weiland, Sharon LaFraniere and Andrew Jacobs

articles.headline: Millions Face Loss of Jobless Aid: ‘Without It, I’m Dead in the Water’
articles.snippet: Emergency federal programs to assist the unemployed in the pandemic will expire at year’s end if there is no congressional action.
articles.abstract: Emergency federal programs to assist the unemployed in the pandemic will expire at year’s end if there is no congressional action.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two critical unemployment programs are set to expire at the end of the year, potentially leaving millions of Americans vulnerable to eviction and hunger and threatening to short-circuit an economic recovery that has already lost momentum.

articles.headline: California Is Trying to Jump-Start the Hydrogen Economy
articles.snippet: The fuel could play an important role in fighting climate change, but it has been slow to gain traction because of high costs.
articles.abstract: The fuel could play an important role in fighting climate change, but it has been slow to gain traction because of high costs.
articles.lead_paragraph: IRVINE, Calif. — Since President George W. Bush fueled a minivan with hydrogen 15 years ago, the promise of cars and trucks powered by the fuel has come up mostly empty.
articles.byline: By Ivan Penn and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: The Election’s Over, but Not the Stress. Any Edibles Left?
articles.snippet: Sales surged as people turned to gummy bears, cookies and chocolates infused with cannabis to soothe their jitters.
articles.abstract: Sales surged as people turned to gummy bears, cookies and chocolates infused with cannabis to soothe their jitters.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — In the weeks leading up to November, Iashia Kilian felt her anxiety deepen.
